Personality variables and presence

  • Helene S. Wallach1,
  • Marilyn P. Safir1 &
  • Roy Samana1 

Virtual Reality volume 14, pages3–13(2010)Cite this article

  • 829 Accesses

  • 28 Citations

  • 0 Altmetric

Abstract

The present study was designed to examine the correlation between five personality traits (empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies and locus of control) and presence. Moreover, this study aimed to identify an optimal virtual reality user’s profile. Eighty-four students (66 women, 18 men) completed personality questionnaires, experienced exposure in a virtual environment and completed a presence questionnaire. Twenty-three women, among them 13 non-Jewish women and no men, neglected to look out the virtual window, and reported lower levels of presence. Presence correlated with immersive tendencies and empathy. However, empathy and internal locus of control were the best predictors for the sense of presence. A correlation between imagination and presence was only found in the group that avoided viewing the virtual window. This study revealed the importance of empathy and internal locus of control in the sense of presence. In addition, our findings suggest that the subject’s imagination has an important role when the virtual environment is restricted and that we must attend to cultural and gender-related factors when investigating therapy using virtual reality technology.

Introduction

Employing virtual reality (VR) technology as an effective alternative to exposure in conventional behavior therapy (BT) has been gaining widespread acceptance for the treatment of a wide range of psychological disorders (Rothbaum et al. 2006). Yet, as with any other treatment, efficacy varies among clients. One of the parameters that have been suggested as increasing efficacy is presence. The term presence, as it is most commonly conceived, refers to the subjective feeling of existence in an experienced environment (Nicovich et al. 2005). In the context of VR presence can be defined as the client/subject’s sense of being within the simulation when he/she is actually not. Therefore, it is both theoretically and practically important to determine the critical elements that contribute to the sense of presence in VR (Banos et al. 2004). One important dimension is the subject’s personality characteristics. Thus, the present study focused on furthering our knowledge of the personality profile that is conducive to increasing presence in VR.

Several personality variables have been examined in relation to the experience of presence. Variables that were found to be unimportant in producing presence are: neuroticism, reactivity to reward and punishment, sensation seeking (Laarni et al. 2004) and the big five personality traits (Sacau et al. 2005). Other variables for which the picture is unclear include: introversion and extraversion (Laarni et al. 2004; Jurnet et al. 2005), absorption (Sas and O’hare 2003; Murray et al. 2007) and self-forgetfulness (Laarni et al. 2004; Ravaja et al. 2004). Six personality variables were found to have a clear association with presence, and five of them were examined in this study. These variables are empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies, locus of control and cognitive style.

Variables impacting on presence

Empathy

Davis (1994) defines empathy as a set of constructs associated with responses of one individual to the experience of another. Empathy involves the ability to engage in the cognitive process of adopting another’s psychological point of view, together with the capacity to experience affective reactions to the observed experienced of others. Nicovich et al. (2005) assumed that the empathy and presence use the same projective “tool set”. They found that as one’s empathic ability increases so does his/her ability to experience presence (R 2 = 0.134). Wickramasekera and Szlyk (2003) found a correlation between empathy and hypnotizability. Sas and O’hare (2003), using the interpersonal reactivity index (Davis 1980) found a significant correlation (0.605) between empathy and presence among 15 subjects. As hypothesized, the index’s fantasy subscale had the highest correlation with the presence (0.753).

Imagination

Mental imagery may be defined as an experience that significantly resembles perceptual experience but which occurs in the absence of appropriate external stimuli for the relevant perception (Thomas 1999). Sas and O’hare (2003) assumed that the ability to imagine, which was found to be related to hypnotizability (Laidlaw and Large 1997) was related to ability to experience presence. They examined the correlation between imagination and presence using Barber and Wilson’s (1979). Creative imagination scale (CIS), a measure that asses the ability to vividly imagine images and situations on demand. They found a significant positive correlation (0.721) between imagination and presence.

Immersive tendencies

Immersive tendencies are a theoretical construct that relates to the tendency to behave playfully and to become involved in a continuous stream of stimuli. Unlike presence, this is a trait. Witmer and Singer (1998) found a significant positive correlation (0.24) between immersive tendencies and presence. Johns et al. (2000) found a significant positive correlation (0.86) between immersive tendencies and presence but only within an environment that included factors that are thought to facilitate presence (for example, a multitude of sensorial information, adequate isolation from the outside world). Laarni et al. (2004) using a different questionnaire to measure presence found that immersive tendencies had a significant main effect in predicting presence.

Dissociation tendencies

Dissociation may be defined as a disruption in the normally integrated functions of consciousness, memory, identity, or perception of the environment (Banos et al. 1999). Murray et al. (2007) found a significant positive correlation (0.308) between the tendency to dissociate and presence. They used a questionnaire that measures three aspects of presence and the dissociative experiences scale (DES) (Bernstein and Putnam 1986).

Locus of control

Locus of control refers to the degree to which a person feels they control events in their own lives, or that such events are influenced by outside forces, chance or luck (Rotter 1966). Murray et al. (2007) found a significant positive correlation (0.218) between locus of control and presence. They hypothesized that people who feel a lack of control over the events in their lives (those with external locus of control), would report a higher sense of presence in the virtual environment. In order to examine the correlation, the researchers used a questionnaire that measures three aspects of presence and Rotter’s (1966) locus of control questionnaire (LoCQ).

Cognitive style

The term cognitive style refers to the unique way in which unconscious mental processes are used in approaching and/or accomplishing cognitive tasks (Sas and O’hare 2003). Sas and O’hare used Myers–Briggs type indicator (Myers and McCaulley 1998) to assess the effect of cognitive style on presence. Both Feeling cognitive style and Sensitive cognitive style correlated with presence.

Personality variables and presence

The present study was designed to investigate whether the five personality traits that had been found to be significantly correlated with presence (empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies and locus of control) could be combined and replicated to increase presence in VR. Although a correlation between cognitive style and presence was found in previous research, it was decided not to include this variable due to its high correlation with empathy, a variable examined in this study (Sas et al. 2004). By increasing the experience of presence, we can enhance the experiences of VR applications.

Thus, our study attempted to replicate previous findings regarding the association between each personality trait and presence using a large sample and a relatively rich environment.

Our hypotheses were

  1. 1.

    A positive correlation will be found between each of the five personality variables (empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies and locus of control) and level of presence.

  2. 2.

    The combination of empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies and locus of control will predict the ability to experience presence in a virtual environment.

Method

Subjects

Eighty-four introductory psychology students (66 female and 18 male) received course credit for participating in this study. Their age ranged from 18 to 30, with a mean of 22. The ethnicity of the majority (57, 67.9%) of the subjects was Jewish.

Materials and measures

The virtual environment

The virtual environment, developed by virtually better, depicted the passenger compartment of an airplane (Fig. 1). By moving one’s head to the left, changing scenery was revealed through the passenger’s window (Fig. 2). Subjects wore a helmet manufactured by Emagin (model 3DVisor Z800), to which an external headphone was connected. Subjects sat on a passenger seat from an Arkia Airlines airplane. The seat was connected to a speaker system (woofers) which caused it to vibrate when appropriate.

Demographics questionnaire

Demographics questionnaire included questions regarding gender, age, and ethnicity.

Empathy

Empathy was measured by the interpersonal reactivity index (IRI, Davis 1980). Although this measure contains four 7-item subscales, only one was used in this study—the Fantasy subscale that measures the tendency to imaginatively transpose one self into fictional situations). The subject is asked to indicate how well each item describes him/her on a 5-point Likert’s scale that ranges from “does not describe me well” (1) to “describes me very well”(5). The internal reliability of the full Hebrew version is α = 0.79 (Shamay-Tsoory et al. 2003). The internal reliability of the fantasy subscale in the original study was α = 0.78 (Davis), and α = 0.79 for the Hebrew version (Shamay-Tsoory et al.). The validity of this subscale was measured by examining its correlation with a similar questionnaire (EES) and a modest correlation of r = 0.48 was found (Davis). An example of an item is: “After seeing a play or movie, I have felt as though I were one of the characters”.

Imagination

Imagination was measured by a shortened version of Betts’ Questionnaire upon Mental Imagery (QMI Sheehan 1967). This questionnaire was chosen since the CIS, which was used in a previous study (Sas and O’hare 2003) is a relatively cumbersome measure. Furthermore, the CISs primary aim is to measure reactivity to hypnotic suggestions and not the ability to imagine. In contrast, the 35 items of the QMI are statements regarding imagery ability in seven different sensory modalities. Subjects are asked to rate their imagery vividness on a 7-point scale. The QMI has high-internal reliability (α = 0.97, Sack et al. 2005). The Hebrew version (Schweitzer 1976) has an internal reliability of α = 0.87 (M. Aflalo, personal communication, 6 May 2008). The validity of the original questionnaire was measured by examining its correlation with a similar questionnaire (VVIQ). A correlation of r = 0.64 was found (Pham et al. 2001(. An example of an item is: “(think of) the smells of new leather”.

Immersive tendencies

Immersive tendencies were measured using the immersive tendencies questionnaire (ITQ) developed by Witmer and Singer (1998). This questionnaire has internal reliability of α = 0.81. The ITQ contains 18 items and consists of three subscales: Focus (items are related to mental alertness, subjects’ ability to concentrate on enjoyable activities and their ability to block out distractions), Involvement (items are related to the subjects’ propensity to get involved passively in some activity) and Games (items question how frequently participants play video games and whether they get involved to the extent that they feel they are within the game). The subject is asked to mark his/her response on a 7-point scale. The Hebrew version, has an internal reliability of α = 0.69. Validity was neither examined in the original nor in the translated version. An example of an item is: “Do you ever become so involved in doing something that you lose all track of time?”

Dissociation tendencies

Dissociation tendencies were measured by the DES. The DES contains 28 items that refer to a variety of dissociative experiences, many of which are normal experiences. Subjects circle the percentage of time that they had the particular experience described in each item on a scale from 0 to 100. DES internal reliability is α = 0.95 (Bernstein and Putnam 1993). The internal reliability of the Hebrew version is r = 0.91 (Somer and Avni 2003). Convergent validity was measured comparing it to a similar questionnaire (PDS), a significant correlation was found (r = 0.59, Somer and Avni). An example of an item is: “Some people have the experience of finding themselves in a place and having no idea how they got there”.

Locus of control

Locus of control was measured by the locus of control questionnaire (LoCQ), whose internal reliability ranges between α = 0.65 and 0.79 (Rotter 1966). The original version contains 29 items. The abbreviated version (11 items) was found to have similar validity to the full version (Valecha and Ostrom 1974), therefore, it was used in this study. Each item is comprises two statements (one an external attribution, one an internal attribution) and the subject is required to choose the one with which they agree the most. Each external attribution that is endorsed receives one point and accordingly the range of possible scores is 0–11. The LoCQ’s Hebrew version has an internal reliability of r = 0.71 (Frankle 1968). Validity was assessed by examining its correlation with various related personality traits and in accordance with the researchers’ expectations significant correlations that attest to its validity were found (e.g. −0.29 with achievement via conformance on CPI and 0.26 with abasement on ACL, Hersch and Scheibe 1967). An example for an item is: “a. in my case getting what I want has little or nothing to do with luck; b. many times we might just as well decide what to do by flipping a coin.”

Presence

Presence was measured by the presence questionnaire (PQ) developed by Witmer and Singer (1998). The PQ contains 19 items and is intended to assess the degree to which the subject felt he/she was “inside” the virtual situation. The subject is asked to mark his/her response on a 7-point scale. The original questionnaire has high-internal reliability α) = 0.88) (Witmer and Singer 1998). The Hebrew version has high-internal reliability as well (α = 0.89, Kizony 2006). Validity was assessed by examining its correlation with simulator sickness during the virtual activity. As predicted, this correlation was negative (r = −0.43). Validity was further assessed by examining the correlation with the ITQ. As expected this correlation was found to be positive (r = 0.24) but relatively weak (Witmer and Singer). An example of an item is: “How much did your experiences in the virtual environment seem consistent with your real-world experiences?”

Procedure

Subjects were recruited through a notice posted on the Psychology Departments Online Bulletin Board. Eight of 92 subjects were excluded because of technical problems that occurred during the VR presentation leaving 84 subjects. Exclusion criterion was fear of flying, none of the subjects reported flight phobia.

Subjects filled out the demographic and personality questionnaires and were given a verbal explanation regarding the virtual experience. They were exposed to a brief (10 min) experience in a virtual environment, and then filled out the presence questionnaire. The virtual simulation was flying in a plane. The plane took off, flew in nice weather, flew in stormy weather and landed. Pearson correlation was used to examine the first hypothesis and a multiple (simultaneous) regression was used to test the second hypothesis. Prior to immersion, the subjects were told that they will sit on an airplane seat wearing a head-mounted display in which they will see and hear a 10-min virtual flight. They were told that they may move their heads and explore their surroundings.

An unexpected finding was noted that some of the subjects did not move their heads during exposure. Thus, a record was made indicating which subjects turned or did not turn their heads and a post hoc analysis was performed on the presence or absence of this behavior.

Results

No significant correlations were found between demographic variables and presence. Thus, there is no difference in the level of presence as a function of demographic variables.

Presence and personality variables

Subjects scored within the normal range on all questionnaires except for the locus of control questionnaire. Mean presence in this study was 83.69, similar to Singer and Witmer (1996) reports of a mean of 84.4. The mean of immersive tendencies was 69.96 in our study, and 73.05 in Witmer and Singer (1998). Level of empathy wasFootnote 1 16.54 in our study and 15.73–18.75 in Davis (1980). Dissociation tendencies were 16.13 in our study and 13.06 in Somer et al. (2001). Imagination wasFootnote 2 106.44 in our study and 98.37 in Jacquith et al. (1996). Locus of control was 4.94 in our study, which was significantly higher than the mean (3.86) reported by Sun (2005) [(t (83) = 4.16, P < 0.01)] (Table 1). This indicates that subjects in our sample tended to be more external.

Differences in level of presence as a function of looking at the window

Twenty-seven percent of our subjects (23 out of 84) failed to look out the virtual window of the plane. Subjects who avoid looking out the window see a more or less static image of the seats in front of them and/or the interior body of the plane. The two groups (window viewers and window avoiders) were compared on level of presence (see Table 2). A significant difference was found. Subjects who looked out the window reported significantly higher levels of presence than those who did not, t (82) = 3.5, P < 0.001. Therefore, looking out the window was treated as an intervening variable.

Factors affecting looking out the window

All the male subjects looked out the window while almost one-third of the female subjects (23 out of 66) did not. Seventy-five percent of Jewish females looked out the window (31 out of 41,), while only 48% of non-Jewish females looked out the window (12 out of 25) (Table 2). Significant associations between ethnicity and window viewing, χ2 (1) = 8.63, P < 0.01, and between gender and window viewing χ2 (1) = 8.64, P < 0.01 were found. Therefore, significantly more non-Jews than Jews and more women than men failed to look out the window.

Correlations between personality variables and presence

We hypothesized that a positive correlation would be found between each of the personality variables (empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies and locus of control) and level of presence. To examine these hypotheses, we conducted five Pearson correlation analyses in the general sample and also separately in the groups of window viewers and window avoiders (see Table 3).

This hypothesis was partly confirmed: in the general sample, the level of presence was positively correlated with immersive tendencies. In the group of window viewers, presence was positively correlated with both immersive tendencies and empathy. In the group of window avoiders, the level of presence was positively and significantly correlated with imagination (Table 3).

The effect of the combination of all five personality variables on presence

We examined the hypothesis that the combination of empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies and locus of control will be related to the ability to experience presence in a virtual environment by employing a multiple regression (simultaneous) analysis (Table 4).

The regression model was significant: F (5, 78) = 2.65, P < 0.05. Percentage of variance of presence explained by the independent variables (immersive tendencies, locus of control, imagination, dissociation tendencies, empathy) was 15%, with a multiple correlation of R = 0.38. Immersive tendencies emerged as the most important component in the correlation, so that the higher the immersive tendencies (B = 0.42, P < 0.05) the higher the level of presence. The correlation between immersive tendencies and presence was 0.29. The rest of the variables added little to the correlation raising it only to 0.38.

As window viewing was considered an intervening variable, a post hoc analysis was performed separately for window avoiders and window viewers.

Among window viewers, the regression model was significant: F (5, 55) = 3.89, P < 0.01. Percentage of variance in presence explained by the personality variables was 26%, the multiple correlation was R = 0.51. External locus of control and level of empathy emerged as the most important components in this group (B = −1.4, P < 0.05), whereby higher internal locus of control, and higher levels of empathy (B = 1.175, P < 0.01), correlated with higher levels of presence. The correlation between these two variables and presence was R = 0.47. The rest of the variables added little to the correlation and raised it only to 0.51 (Table 5).

Although immersive tendencies had a positive correlation with presence, this variable did not significantly contribute to the prediction in the regression. This may be due to the relatively strong correlation between immersive tendencies and empathy (r = 0.67, P < 0.001).

Finally, for window avoiders the regression model results were not significant: F (5, 17) = 1.27 n.s. Therefore, personality variables did not predict level of presence for window avoiders (Table 6). This may be a result of the small sample size of this group.

Discussion

Our study had two aims: to determine whether associations found in previous studies between personality traits and presence could be replicated; and to identify an optimal profile for the VR subject/client.

The first hypothesis was that five personality variables (empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies and locus of control) would correlate with presence in the virtual environment (VE). However, a significant positive correlation was found only between presence and immersive tendencies in the group as a whole and presence and both immersive tendencies and empathy in the window viewer group.

The second hypothesis was that the combination of the five personality variables would predict presence. This hypothesis was also only partially supported. Only immersive tendencies in the group as a whole and only immersive tendencies, locus of control and empathy in the window viewers group significantly contributed to the prediction of presence.

Twenty-seven percent of subjects failed to look out the virtual window during the VR presentation. Therefore, the results for window viewers and window avoiders were analyzed separately and found that window viewers had significantly higher presence ratings.

The first hypothesis was only partly confirmed for the window avoiders—a significant positive correlation was found between imagination and presence. The second hypothesis was not confirmed. For the window viewer group, the first hypothesis was partly confirmed—a significant positive correlation was found between presence and both immersion and empathy. The second hypothesis was also only partly confirmed for this group. Empathy and locus of control were found to have a significant contribution in prediction of presence. In contrast to our hypothesis, internal locus of control correlated positively with presence. The other personality variables did not significantly contribute to the prediction. In total, the model was able to explain 26% of the variance.

Subjects who looked out the virtual window of the plane reported a higher sense of presence than subjects who avoided looking. The sense of presence is effected by two technological variables: vividness and interactivity (Schubert et al. 2001; Steuer 1992). Sensorial breadth and sensorial depth of the stimuli are associated with vividness. These variables affect the involuntary attention, the subject/client allocates to the virtual environment (Wirth et al. 2007). By not looking out the virtual window, the window avoiders lost visual stimuli which subtracted from the sensorial depth of the stimuli and thus reduced their sense of presence.

There are several possible explanations as to why some of our subjects avoided looking out the window: 1. Fear that looking would increase anxiety which would lead to emotional flooding; 2. Lack of interest in experiencing the virtual environment or lack of motivation to actively experience it. Motivation has an effect on attention allocation in virtual experiences, and attention allocation has, in turn, an effect on level of presence (Laarni et al. 2004); 3. Subjects who did not experience the virtual environment as realistic, did not actively engage in it, and, therefore, did not look around. However, all window avoiders were female, and significantly more non-Jewish women avoided looking out the window. We would like to offer an explanation for this difference that is related to the situational characteristics of the study. Subjects sat in a closed dark room with a male experimenter. This VR experience may have aroused discomfort in some of our female subjects, in particular those that are from more traditional and/or minority (non-Jewish) culture; thus, interfering with them actively engaging in the virtual experience. Despite the exposure to contemporary Israeli culture, Arab society tends to be more religious, traditional and conservative and there are clear restrictions on different aspects of women’s life (Sherer and Sherer 2008). This may have influenced the disparity in percentages of window avoiders between the Jewish and the Arab women. Thus, we propose to specifically study both the culture and ethnicity as well as gender in future research. For these reasons and that the number of male subjects was small, and was comprised few non-Jewish males, we must be cautious in interpreting these results.

Locus of control and presence

The correlation between locus of control and presence was not significant; however, locus of control was a significant predictive variable in the multiple regression analysis. These conflicting results may be explained by taking into account that our subjects scored significantly higher on the external scale than results reported in previous studies (e.g. Sun 2005; Valecha and Ostrom 1974).

Witmer and Singer (1998) claim that the more control one feels over the virtual environment or over interaction within it, the more presence one experiences. Because all the subjects in our study were exposed to the identical technology with the same control options, there is no doubt that much is left up to subjective sense of control (Slater 1999). Therefore, finding that internal locus of control predicts presence is not surprising. People who feel in control over events in their lives (internal locus of control) focus on elements they are able to control while those who feel they lack control (external locus of control) focus on elements they cannot control (Lefcourt 1982).

In contradiction with our findings, Murray et al. (2007) found a positive correlation between external locus of control and presence. This may have resulted from brevity of their presence questionnaire. The SUS includes only six items, none of which examine the locus of control factor. Witmer and Singer (1998) argued that “(a sense of) control … is essential for a strong sense of presence” (p. 239). Their contention finds support in our results. In addition, Hair et al. (2007) found that a negative correlation exists between external locus of control and the ability to ignore distractions, an ability that is crucial in developing and maintaining presence (Wirth et al. 2007). Furthermore, Taylor et al. (2006) found that the tendency to experience flow has a positive correlation with internal locus of control, while Jacobson (2002) stated that the feeling of presence can be conceptualized as a “flow experience”.

We remain to be cautious even though the association between locus of control and presence was salient in the multiple regression analysis, as the partial correlation between locus of control and presence was non-significant. In addition, as previously mentioned, our sample was higher on external LOC than in previous studies (e.g. Sun 2005; Valecha and Ostrom 1974). Thus, additional research is necessary to tease out the association between these variables.

Immersive tendencies and presence

As predicted, and in accordance with previous studies (for example, Witmer and Singer 1998), a correlation was found between immersive tendencies and presence. Immersive tendencies appear to be related to cognitive and behavioral aspects such as concentration, imagination and self-control (Psotka and Davidson cited in Kaber et al. 2002). People high on immersive tendencies can ignore external distractions and focus on their experiences so that they are unaware of their immediate environment and the passage of time. These people tend to be playful, spontaneous, creative and imaginative (Webster and Martocchio 1992; Newman 2005), passively involved in different activities, and to feel as if they are within video games they play (Witmer and Singer).

Although a correlation was found between immersive tendencies and presence, immersive tendencies failed to play a major role in the multiple regression analysis. This may be the result of the strong correlation (r = 0.67) between empathy and immersive tendencies.

Empathy and presence

Our study found a positive correlation between empathy and presence. These results replicate Nicovich et al.’s (2005) findings. Nicovich et al. proposed that presence, like empathy, is a form of emotional projection. Thus, presence may be understood as an emotional connection to a place, as opposed to the cognitive recognition of being in a space. They propose that the emotional connection strengthens the bond between the subject and his/her virtual environment. Following Nicovich et al. (2005), we employed the fantasy aspect of empathy which is defined as the person’s tendency to identify strongly with fictional characters in books, movies, etc. (Davis 1980). Nicovich et al. (2005) chose to examine fantasy because their virtual environment, like ours, did not include avatars (characters) with which the user may interact. Therefore, other aspects of empathy become irrelevant.

Imagination and presence

One of the most interesting findings of our study is the significant correlation between imagination and presence which was found in the window avoiders group. We had predicted a correlation in both groups based on Sas and O’Hare’s (2003) findings. However, one reason for the difference between these two studies may have occurred as the questionnaire they used is actually a measure of hypnotic susceptibility (Yu 2005) rather than a measure of imaginative ability. As a result of Yu’s critique, we choose to employ a measure of imaginative ability (Sheehan 1967). Therefore, our study is actually the first to examine the correlation between presence and imagination. In addition, Sas and O’Hare chose to use a relatively primitive virtual environment, whereas we employed an advanced technological environment.

As stated previously, vividness has an impact on presence (for example, Biocca et al. 2001). Thus when the VE is rich, imagination does not have much significance as the subject does not need to employ imagination in order to experience the environment as convincing. However, when there are technological limitations as in Sas and O’Hare’s (2003) study, or when, as in the present case, there some subjects limited their utilization of the technological capabilities, the sensorial depth of the stimuli is decreased (Steuer 1992) and it is necessary to use imaginative ability to fill in what is missing (Jacobson 2001). This is also in accord with both Wirth et al. (2007) claim that “…spatial imagination becomes more relevant if the mediated representation of the space is less intuitive and more fragmented” (p. 502) and Lee’s (2004) claim that when an environment is poor in sensorial stimuli, imagination can simulate the missing sensorial cues, thus creating a convincing sense of realism. It should be noted that these claims were not previously experimentally tested in the context of VR.

Dissociation tendencies and presence

In contrast with two previous studies that found significant correlations between presence and dissociation, our study failed to find such a correlation. Banos et al.’s (2004) study is problematic, presence was examined by one item only. Although the sample in Murray et al.’s (2007) study was composed of a non-clinical pool of students, average dissociation tendencies score was quite high, equal to that of patient groups such as PTSD patients (Somer et al. 2001). Therefore, Murray et al. results do not properly represent the normal population. We hypothesize that only when dissociation tendencies levels are very high do they correlate with presence.

Suggestions for future studies

Our study examined the correlation between fantasy aspects of empathy and presence. It seems advisable to investigate additional aspects of empathy as well. Perhaps, when avatars appear in the VE, perspective taking, empathic concern and personal distress (Davis 1980) will have greater relevance and contribute to sense of presence. It seems worthwhile to examine the correlation between feeling-type cognitive style and presence. People with this cognitive style are relatively more empathic than people with other cognitive styles (Sas and O’Hare 2003).

That almost one-third of our subjects were immobile in the VE may have contributed to the ambiguous findings regarding the association between locus of control and presence. It is advisable to examine this association, with a more interactive environment and to give more explicit instructions to look in all possible directions.

Robillard et al. (2003) reported that phobic subjects had higher immersive tendencies in comparison to non-phobic subjects as well as a higher sense of presence when they were close to the virtual phobic object. Therefore, it seems worthwhile to replicate our study with subjects who suffer from anxieties or phobia related to flying followed by a treatment regime for these anxieties. Such facilities were unavailable within the context of this experiment.

Practical implications

That a significant correlation was found between window viewing and presence has an important practical implication. Thus, we suggest that it is advisable to introduce the VE to subjects before the actual exposure so that they are able to perceive all that it contains or to give them more explicit instructions requesting that they look in all directions. If the negative correlation between presence and window-avoidance results from a lack of motivation or from a lack of sense of presence, it seems that explicit preexposure or instructions to look at all the visual objects may contribute to motivation to take part in the experience (in the first case) and to their sense of presence (in the second case). We would like to suggest that clients suffering from flight phobia might avoid looking out the window as a means of controlling their anxiety. If we are correct, it is important that the therapist insist that clients turn their attention to these sights, for therapy to be effective.

In view of our suggestion that the experimenters’ male gender may have influenced female subjects’ behavior in the VE, it is necessary to employ experimenters of both genders, as well as to explore the influence of cultural differences in future studies.

As a result of the positive correlation between imagination and presence in some subjects, and concern that giving up the use of imagination in therapy might subtract from clients’ potential toolbox, we would like to suggest that imaginal exposure should not be abandoned. Exposure using VR may be combined with imaginal exposure in various ways, for instance: using VE in early stages of therapy and then moving on to the use of guided imagery techniques. Different combinations may be suitable for different patients.

Methodological issues

The sample in our study was comprises psychology students, a group that is not representative of the general population and only about 20% of our subjects were male. Our subjects also received course credit for their participation. In addition, potential subjects who suffered from flight phobia were excluded from this study on ethical grounds, limiting the generalizability of our findings. Phobic subjects feel a higher sense of presence when they are close to the phobic object. In addition, it should be mentioned again that our sample was comprised of people who tended to have a more external locus of control scores than generally reported. Finally, it is important to emphasize that the validity of the ITQ has not been examined.

Summary

Our study had two aims: to determine whether associations found in previous studies between personality traits and presence could be replicated; and to determine an optimal profile for the VR subject/client. The first hypothesis was that five personality variables (empathy, imagination, immersive tendencies, dissociation tendencies and locus of control) would correlate with presence in the virtual environment (VE). However, a significant positive correlation was found only between presence and immersive tendencies in the group as a whole and between presence and both immersive tendencies and empathy in the window viewer group. The second hypothesis was that the combination of the five personality variables would predict presence. This hypothesis was also only partially supported. Only immersive tendencies in the group as a whole and only immersive tendency, locus of control and empathy in the window viewers group significantly contributed to the prediction of presence.

Presence is an active and creative process influenced by technology’s advancements as well as by subject characteristics (Hecht and Reiner 2007). However, few studies focused on the impact of individual subject variables on presence. Furthermore, most of these studies were content with examining the role of cognitive abilities and few examined personality traits (Sacau et al. 2008). The few that did so often employed technology that is out dated by today’s technology, and they were limited in the number of personality traits that they examined.

In recent years, a number of different variables have been studied in relation to presence but empathy and locus of control consistently appear as prominent variables. Our findings support the importance of empathy and locus of control in predicting presence. Thus, we suggest that information regarding one’s tendency to feel a sense of control with information about the tendency to project him/her self into fictional situations may help us predict one’s ability to feel presence in the virtual environment.

Based on the Sacau et al.’s (2008) claim that the difficulty in analyzing factors that influence the sense of presence stems from different effects which may vary from one media form to another, and the effect of these different factors may interact in a complex way with the properties of the media stimuli that is employed, it seems advisable to re-examine these variables in different virtual environments. Our findings suggest that imagination plays an important role when the VE is limited.

As Sacau et al. (2008) pointed out a great deal of money could be saved if VR-based psychotherapy, for instance, is employed for those clients who are most likely to benefit from it. However, we agree with their conclusion that much more research is needed before we are able to select patients according to their ability to experience presence. In light of the relatively small percent of variance explained by empathy and locus of control, it seems necessary to examine additional personality variables that may affect the presence. In addition, our findings suggest that it is important to examine cultural and gender-related issues. There is no doubt, that despite progress, research on presence is still in its infancy. We hope that our study, may contribute to the continuing advancement in this important field of study.
